results.title: Play Loud
results.brief_description:
The distinctive Australian ‘pub rock’ sound was born in the hotels and bars of our major cities in the 1970s.
In the Melbourne scene, the ‘beer barns’ of the suburbs were complemented by smaller, more intimate venues in the city and inner suburbs of Carlton, Richmond, Fitzroy and St Kilda.
This film - made in his student days by award-winning producer Daniel Scharf - presents a 1979 performance by the Melbourne band ‘Cuban Heels’ at one such venue, ‘Hearts’ in Carlton.
The atmosphere of alcohol, cigarette-smoke and youthful exuberance is captured by the camera as it wanders through the audience and lingers on the dancers.
On stage, the band (led by Steve Connolly, who was later the guitarist with Paul Kelly’s ‘Coloured Girls’ and ‘Messengers’ bands) sings a song that could only be a product of the 1970s - about ‘the system’ and the coming revolution.

results.title: On the Line
results.creator_credit: David Greig, John Richardson, SBS-TV and Kestrel Films & Video (Australia)
results.brief_description: It’s a harsh, lonely life for the men, mostly European migrants, who work maintaining the railway around Redmont in north-west Western Australia. Labouring through searing heat over 426 kilometres of mountainous, desert region, these men talk candidly about their lives, providing psychological and social insight into what it is to be living in “isolation”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Greig, John Richardson, SBS-TV and Kestrel Films & Video (Australia)

results.title: Fight for Country
results.creator_credit: Pip Starr, Bill Runting and Rockhopper Productions
results.brief_description: In 1998, over 5,000 people travelled to Kakadu, in the Northern Territory, to stand alongside the traditional owners of the land, the Mirrar people, and lend their support to the Jabiluka Campaign. The fight to prevent the development of the Jabiluka uranium mine was one of the biggest protest movements in Australia’s history and over 600 people were arrested in the process. It took film-maker Pip Starr four years to make this film, including one year spent documenting these historic events.

results.title: Rabbit Control [Part 1: Poisoning with 1080]
results.creator_credit: Ian Blythman, John Atkins and Conservation Forests and Lands
results.brief_description: This program narrated by Maurie Fields shows the problem of pest control in rural Victoria, and the adverse effects on farming if rabbit populations are not controlled. Part 1 explains the proper steps and procedure in using the poison 1080, the various safety precautions, equipment and supplies and tidy up details.

results.title: Using a computer catalogue
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, Jenny Craig, Keith Rees, Healthsharing Women. Publishing and Production Group and TV Ed Productions
results.brief_description: Because of changing library information systems, computerised catalogues are increasingly being used to record, store and retrieve holdings in libraries. Ann Hannan demostrates how to use the OPAC (On Line Public Access Catalogue) System, which is a touch system used in public libraries.

results.title: Adventure Games in the Classroom
results.creator_credit: Stephen Skok and Victoria. Ministry of Education

results.title: Communication without speech
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, George Cass and TV Ed Productions
results.brief_description: Recent advances in technology have enabled the development of a range of sophisticated communication devices which, with the assistance of microprocessors, enables students with severe communication impairment to communicate, using voice and print.

results.title: Punching keys
results.creator_credit: Sally Ingleton and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: A biting dramatisation of the effects of the new technology in deskilling the female office workforce, alienating women from the products of their labour, and rendering them replaceable by cheaper labour overseas. Cast includes a young Gina Riley.

results.title: The Melbourne Concert Hall
results.creator_credit: David Greig, David Morgan, The Victorian Arts Centre and Kestrel Films (Australia)
results.brief_description: Interviews with architects, administrators, interior designers, construction workers and others associated with the construction of the Melbourne Concert Hall. Artists who have performed at the venue also give their opinion of hall. Those interviewed include: Roy Ground, Neil Haysom, Theodore Schultz, Ken Myer, John Truscott and Kenny Christophers. Shows segments from performances by Jackie Love, Cleo Laine, Sylvio Gualdo, Karen Knowles, London Early Music Group, Mondo Rock, the guitarist John Williams, Brian May’s Melbourne Showband and conductors Piero Gamba, Patrick Thomas and John Hopkins. Views of Melbourne’s skyline capture the Gas and Fuel buildings that were demolished to accommodate Federation Square.
